Award.AwardTitle: Toward a Method for Achieving Synergy between Heuristic Rules of Thumb and Quantitative Methods in Engineering Design

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Engineering design experts' heuristic "rules of thumb" usually save time and money when making design decisions. Through years of experience with product design, materials, and manufacturing, experts can perform many design tasks quickly, such as narrowing the set of possible design options to investigate further. Sometimes, however, these shortcuts result in poor design decisions that waste time and money. This happens especially when new materials, manufacturing technologies, or types of products are being considered. The old rules of thumb no longer apply, and even experts can be vulnerable to "cognitive biases," or decision traps that we all sometimes fall into. Although mathematical models and approaches can alleviate this problem, they often require significant cost and effort to implement and therefore counteract the desired benefit. This project will benefit society by combining the best of both worlds, working toward a methodology for determining the best balance between rapid heuristic strategies and more rigorous quantitative methods for making design decisions.

The intellectual significance of this project lies in building a foundation for a new, formal design methodology that exploits the synergy between heuristic and normative methods. This project will analyze a design process for one advanced systems engineering problem, where the designer is required to expand the frame of analysis to include issues never before considered. Normative methods such as optimization and decision-based design consider efficiency and tradeoffs under uncertainty with the same degree of analytic rigor that was previously applied only to physical system modeling. While this approach has been successful to some extent, there are times when the cost of this approach (formulation, data gathering, solving) is simply not worth the effort. Conversely, the heuristic "rules of thumb" employed by design experts are faster, but can sometimes lead to suboptimal results because of systematic cognitive biases that are inadvertently embedded in the heuristic and lead the design choice away from the optimal solution. The problem addressed here is that strictly heuristic design methods can lead to inferior solutions, while strictly normative methods can be too time consuming and costly to implement. Observed heuristics will be analyzed to determine their effect on both the design process and the resulting product. Normative methods will be analyzed in the same manner. Then, a method for defining the best combination of the two approaches will be developed. This project will provide the foundation for developing a full set of "rules for rational design analysis" for determining the best combination of normative and heuristic approaches.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on decision-making in engineering design, specifically addressing challenges that arise as engineers work to tackle larger and more complicated system design problems. A spectrum of strategies exist for supporting design decisions, ranging from heuristic (expert intuition) and procedure-based design (PBD), to system design optimization methods based on high-fidelity computer simulations. The former are easier to implement, but may not always lead to desired performance (especially as system complexity increases beyond the limits of human intuition). The latter, when implemented well, can help reveal non-intuitive high-performance design solutions, but often requires significant investment in model development, validation, and optimization studies. Part of this project dealt with the question: “Is the investment in more sophisticated design decision support strategies worthwhile?”. We investigated the concept of hybrid solution methods, where some decisions are made using established guidelines from PBD methods, and the remainder are made using design optimization. We created a systematic method for evaluating hybrid design decision strategies, and discovered that in some cases a hybrid strategy can result in solutions very close to optimal with much less overall effort than a pure optimization solution strategy.

 

Another core aspect of this project that emerged was an investigation of methods for system design problem formulation, especially guidelines (explicit or implicit) that engineers use to navigate problem formulation options. A design method involves both a problem formulation and a solution strategy. Often in design activities engineers iterate between problem formulation and solution, refining formulations to account for factors unknown before initial solution attempts, and selecting different solution methods to accommodate changing problem properties. When using design optimization methods, skill in problem formulation requires specialized knowledge, spanning not only optimization theory and algorithms, but engineering domain knowledge and problem formulation techniques. Elements of this specialized knowledge are easily obtained via education in numerical methods or application domain fundamentals. Other elements, especially problem formulation, are normally only developed successfully through significant experience in design optimization practice.

 

In this project we sought to understand how experienced design optimization practitioners made problem formulation decisions. In some cases practitioners are consciously aware of the reasoning behind these decisions (e.g., mathematical justifications, adherence to guidelines for best practices). In other cases these decisions are made using intuition derived from experience. Publications resulting from this project identified the rationale behind problem formulation decisions that previously was not explicit. We gathered design optimization problem formulation guidelines, both from the literature and from our studies, to provide a foundation for assessing the effectiveness of available guidelines. We defined a systematic, quantitative method for testing guidelines that could serve as a basis for future studies that would further advance the goals of this project.

 

The outcomes of this project contribute both to the engineering design literature and to society by helping engineers make better design and problem formulation decisions. Specifically, we hope that new insights gained regarding explicit design optimization problem formulation guidelines will accelerate the development of the specialized knowledge required for effective application of design optimization methods. Rather than requiring years of experience to develop accurate intuition for effective problem formulation strategies, making these guidelines more explicit may help engineering practitioners to achieve formulation proficiency in shorter time periods. The outcomes of this project are being incorporated into an applied design optimization course for senior undergraduate students to help accelerate mastery of problem formulation skills. Future work could involve investigating what formulation teaching techniques are most effective, both in a university and an industry training setting. A central motivation for improving accessibility of design optimization methods to a larger set of engineering practitioners is to help advance the quality of engineering design decisions more broadly across society. Realizing this accessibility could impact any area where improved engineering design is critical for advancement, including, but not limited to, areas such as energy efficiency and sustainability, transportation, cyber-physical systems, and other critical infrastructure.
